Institute of Molecular Catalysis and In-situ/operando Studies, Institute of Molecular Engineering Plus, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350108 China PtSn bimetallic catalysts applied in propane dehydrogenation (PDH) reaction suffer from deactivation at high temperatures (500–700 °C) due to metal segregation and Sn-rich cluster formation. This study demonstrates that supporting PtSn catalysts on Silicalite-1 zeolite (S-1) enhances Sn dispersion through interactions with silanol hydroxyl groups, enabling effective regeneration of Pt-rich PtSn clusters even after 15 reaction-regeneration cycles. Comprehensive characterizations reveal that silanol nests play a critical role in redispersing metal species during regeneration, minimizing aggregation, and maintaining catalytic activity. The enhanced metal-support interactions significantly improve catalyst regenerability and stability, addressing key challenges in industrial PDH processes. This work highlights the importance of Sn dispersion and metal-support interactions in designing durable and efficient PtSn catalysts, offering practical insights for sustainable propylene production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Propane dehydrogenation Propylene Silanol Catalyst regeneration PtSn catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is a critical petrochemical intermediate utilized in the production of important chemicals like polypropylene, acrylonitrile, and acrylic acid. Global propylene production capacity has consistently increased in recent decades, driven by rising downstream product demand [1–4]. Propylene is currently produced primarily through steam cracking, catalytic cracking, propane dehydrogenation, and coal-to-olefin processes [5–7]. However, as fossil fuels deplete and shale gas becomes more available, the feedstock for propylene manufacturing shifts from pricey naphtha to lighter propane. This transition has considerably aided the rise of nonoxidative propane dehydrogenation (PDH) as a major global pathway for propylene synthesis [8–10]. Propane is a chemically stable molecule, requiring substantial energy to break its CH bonds during dehydrogenation [11], the reaction conducted under high temperatures (500–700 °C) [12–14]. Currently, PDH technology is widely applied in industrial propylene production, primarily through the Catofin and the Oleflex process, which employs CrOx catalysts and Pt-based catalysts [15–19]. Compared to CrOx-based catalysts, Pt-based catalysts have significant environmentally friendly properties [20–24]. However, its deactivation associated with complex catalyst structure evolution during high-temperature dehydrogenation still needs further study [25–29]. Simultaneously, realizing the regeneration of the PtSn bimetallic catalysts during PDH operation is the goal of this field. The deactivation reasons of the catalysts are mainly attributed to two factors: coke formation and metal sintering [21,26,30–32]. Specifically, low Taman temperature and mismatched activity properties of precious metals lead to sintering and coking, presenting a challenge in both research and industrial contexts. The aggregated large metal nanoparticles act as side-active sites for propane cracking and coke formation. Notably, favorable metal-support interactions are mandatory for redispersing the aggregated metal nanoparticles in PDH catalyst regeneration. In a typical practice, catalysts are regenerated under oxidizing or oxychlorination conditions to mitigate surface coke deposition, followed by H2 reduction to restore its activity. However, realizing the redispersion of sintered precious metals through regeneration remains a high challenge [31,33,34]. To date, much progress has been made to enhance the stability and the regeneration performance of PtSn catalysts [35–37]. Pham et al. [31] prepared PtSn/γ-Al2O3 catalysts using the impregnation method and observed that the addition of Sn to Pt/γ-Al2O3 enhanced propylene selectivity. Sn provided nucleation sites that facilitated the redispersion of Pt atoms, regenerating sub-nanometer Pt clusters in oxidatively regenerated catalysts. They also noted that larger Pt3Sn particles (∼10 nm) in Pt-Sn/γ-Al2O3 exhibited lower propane dehydrogenation activity. Ren et al. [34] demonstrated that the regeneration of sintered Pt-based catalysts using H2O2 and HCl at 70 °C could weaken Pt–Pt bonds and extract Pt atoms from the surface of sintered particles, achieving redispersion and regeneration of Pt sites. Xiong et al. [33] developed a thermally stable, active, and regenerable Pt-Sn/CeO2 catalyst. The atom trapping sites on CeO2 enabled complete redispersion of Pt atoms under mild oxidative regeneration conditions, eliminating the need for chlorine-containing chemicals. Deng et al. [38] studied Pt-Sn/SiO2 catalysts and found that introducing H2 into the feed gas helped preserve the active species on the catalyst surface. This reduction-regeneration technique partially recovered the active Pt-Sn alloy phases. During oxidation–reduction regeneration, Sn was isolated from the Pt-Sn alloy during calcination and was then re-alloyed with Pt under reduction conditions. This process enhanced Pt-Sn interactions, leading to a significant recovery in catalytic activity. Sun et al. [39] conducted continuous reaction-regeneration cycles of Pt-Sn/γ-Al2O3 catalysts using various regeneration methods. They discovered that hydrogen regeneration offered the best stability compared to nitrogen purging and coke-burning treatments. Hydrogen regeneration not only removed low-density coke components but also increased the accessibility of metal active sites. In sum, effectively regenerating deactivated PtSn catalysts is still an underestimated challenge for the utilization of PtSn catalysts for PDH systems, which needs a deeper understanding of metal-to-metal and metal-to-support interactions for predictive catalyst design [4,40]. In this study, a PtSn/S-1 catalyst was synthesized using the co-impregnation method with modified Silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite. It is demonstrated that supporting the PtSn bimetallic catalyst in S-1 zeolite can effectively disperse the Sn species by enhancing the interaction between Sn and the abundant silanol hydroxyl groups inside the zeolite. This interaction enables the regeneration of active Pt-rich PtSn clusters, even after 15-round continuous reaction-regeneration cycles. The comprehensive characterizations reveal that the enhanced catalytic performance and regenerability are attributed to the silanol nest that redisperses the metal species during the regeneration process. This process enhances the uniform redistribution of Pt and Sn species across the S-1 support, minimizing metal aggregation and promoting the generation of highly active bimetallic sites. Such a mechanism plays in maintaining catalytic activity and stability, as evidenced by the improved propane conversion and consistent performance observed after multiple regeneration cycles. This work highlights the critical role of Sn dispersion and metal-support interactions in maintaining the regenerability of PtSn catalysts in PDH. 2 Catalyst synthesis All chemicals and materials are applied in this work without further purification, as follows: Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 (Pt, 50 % basis, Sigma-Aldrich), SnCl2⋅2H2O (98 %, Aladdin). In a typical synthesis according to our previous work, [41] A syringe pump was used to add 10.0 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, AR, SiO2 ≥ 28.4 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) to a combination of 21.45 g H2O and 11.71 g of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt % in water, Energy Chemical Co., Ltd.) at a rate of 100 μL/min. The liquid was swirled in an ice bath for an hour before being heated to 70 degrees Celsius for three hours. Then, add 12.0 g of isopropanol (IPA, AR, ≥ 99.7 %, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) dropwise at a rate of 500 μL/min and stir for 20 min. The gel's molar composition was 1 SiO2, 4 IPA, 0.3 TPAOH, and 35 H2O. The precursor solution was then heated in an oven at 170 °C for four days. After repeated washing and drying, the powers were calcined in air at 550 °C for 6 h, with a heating rate of 1 °C per minute. PtSn/S-1 was prepared using the co-impregnation process. The specific process is as follows: weigh 0.0030 g of chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate and 0.0092 g of stannous chloride (dihydrate) and add 1 mL of H2O and 100 μL of HCl, completely dissolve and then drop into 1.00 g of S-1 powder and mix with vigorous stirring, and then put the resulting mixture into an 80 °C oven to dry for 24 h after aging for 2 h at room temperature, and then raise the temperature to 500 °C for 4 h at a heating rate of 3 °C /min in air to obtain the catalyst. Catalysts with a nominal content of 0.2Pt0.5Sn/S-1 were obtained. The actual Pt content and Sn content of the catalysts were determined by ICP-OES (Table S1). The characterization details and the propane dehydrogenation experiments are summarized in the Section 1 and 2 in the Electronic Supplementary Information. 3 Propane dehydrogenation activity and regeneration performance The regeneration performance of PtSn catalysts supported on pure silica support is a critical evaluation criterion. In this study, the PtSn/S-1 catalyst underwent 15 continuous PDH-regeneration cycles at 550 °C and 1 bar. The propane conversion and propylene selectivity for each cycle are summarized in Fig. 1 , Figure S1 and Table S2. The PtSn/S-1 catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability, maintaining high propylene selectivity (>95 %) throughout all regeneration cycles. Notably, the initial propane conversion was approximately 22.3 % during the first reaction cycle but declined to about 15.4 % after 6 h of operation. Following the first regeneration, the initial propane conversion significantly increased to ∼44 %, suggesting that the regeneration process effectively redispersed the catalyst, thereby generating additional active sites and enhancing catalytic performance. Four catalysts from different stages of the reaction process were selected for further analysis: PtSn/S-1–1F, PtSn/S-1–1U, PtSn/S-1–2F, and PtSn/S-1–15U. The suffix of the terms refers to the catalyst after a certain reaction cycle, the letter F and U is assigned to the fresh and used catalyst, respectively. For example, PtSn/S-1–1F stands for the fresh catalyst in the 1st PDH-regeneration cycle, while PtSn/S-1–15U is the used catalyst after the 15th continuous PDH-regeneration cycle. Comparative studies revealed that the activity and regeneration performance of PtSn/Al2O3 catalysts, synthesized using the same method, were significantly inferior to those of PtSn/S-1. The PtSn/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited <20 % C3H8 conversion, and although the conversion could be partially recovered through O2 regeneration, the deactivation occurred rapidly, and the recovery was notably less effective compared to PtSn/S-1. (Figure S2). The catalytic activity of the PtSn/S-1–1F catalyst remained essentially unchanged after calcination at 500 °C or 550 °C, as demonstrated in Figure S3. 4 Characterization of the PtSn/S-1 catalyst 4.1 Structural analysis of catalysts The structure of the PtSn/S-1 catalyst was investigated by comprehensive characterizations. The pore structure of the prepared PtSn/S-1 catalyst was analyzed by N2 physisorption. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the adsorption branches of PtSn/S-1–1F catalyst and S-1 zeolite exhibit a type II pattern for microporous materials. The N2 uptake of the S-1 support is higher than that of the PtSn/S-1 catalyst, which indicates that the introduction of the metal greatly affects the pore structure. Based on the XRD results indicate that the crystalline phase structure of the both catalysts retained the characteristic peaks of MFI zeolite. In addition, no diffraction peaks corresponding to Pt or PtSn crystalline phases were observed, indicating that the Pt and Sn species are either highly dispersed in the support S-1, or present at concentrations too low to be detected by XRD. As shown in Table 1 , the deposition of PtSn nanoparticles leads to significant decreases in meso‑ and microporosity, implying pore occupation by metal species. Moreover, the introduction of the metal impacts the pore structure of S-1 without altering its overall physical properties. To gain deeper insights into the morphology of the metal particles, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy were conducted to evaluate the dispersion of Pt and Sn species in the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3 (a-f), many irregular particles are visible in the PtSn/S-1–1F catalyst. EDS analysis in Fig. 3(g-j) further reveals that the metal species tend to aggregate, with Pt and Sn forming bimetallic PtSn assemblies. In Fig. 4 , larger clusters of metal Pt metal are observed alongside smaller Sn particles. The pronounced clustering of Pt led to a rapid decline in the PDH catalytic activity. Conversely, for the catalyst PtSn/S-1–2F, TEM images in Figure S4 demonstrate that the metal particles on the S-1 zeolite are almost entirely dispersed, with significantly reduced agglomeration. EDS analysis further confirms the improved dispersion of Pt and Sn species. This enhanced dispersion contributes to improved catalytic activity for the propane dehydrogenation reaction. Subsequent observations from Figure S5(a-f) reveal the presence of a few metal clusters on the catalyst after 15 rounds of reaction-regeneration cycles. EDS analysis confirms that the dispersion of the Pt and Sn deteriorates slightly compared to earlier cycles; however, the metals remain more dispersed overall than in the fresh catalyst as shown in Figure S5(g-j). Notably, no large metal particles or clusters are detected in the PtSn/S-1–2F and PtSn/S-1–15U catalysts. EDS imaging further corroborates that Pt and Sn species undergo redispersion during the regeneration treatment, which aligns well with the observed enhancement in propane conversion. In summary, TEM results indicate that the regeneration treatment facilitates the redispersion of PtSn bimetallic species, thereby restoring the catalyst's initial activity. 4.2 Chemical characterization of catalysts The metal-support interactions were investigated using FT-IR spectroscopy in the Si-OH stretching vibration region (Fig. 5 a) and 29Si MAS NMR (Fig. 5b and Table S3). All the FT-IR spectra have been normalized at 1880 cm-1. In the IR spectra, two prominent peaks were observed at 3720 and 3675 cm-1. The peak at 3720 cm-1 corresponds to the isolated internal silanol nests [42], while the peak at 3675 cm-1 is associated with Sn-OH groups. With increasing regeneration cycles, the Sn-OH peak intensity gradually decreased, which may be attributed to the dispersion of Sn-OH species under oxygen exposure. Notably, the lowest Sn-OH peak intensity observed for PtSn/S-1–2F suggests complete dispersion of Sn-OH species, leading to an increase in accessible active sites and enhanced catalytic activity. Furthermore, the metal-support interactions of the catalysts were demonstrated using 29Si MAS NMR (Fig. 5b and Table S3). The resonance at −103.4 ppm is allocated to the framework Si-OH groups (Si(OSi)3(OH), Q3), while the other bands at 113.1 and −115.9 ppm are assigned to framework Si(SiO)4 species (Q4) [43,44]. As the reaction progressed, the Q3 groups at −103.4 ppm decreased, aligning with the FT-IR results and indicating that Pt and/or Sn species were trapped by the silanol nests of the S-1 zeolite. These findings collectively highlight the dynamic metal-support interactions and their role in stabilizing active species during the reaction and regeneration cycles. The following UV–Vis spectra further support this observation (Fig. 5c). All catalysts exhibit an absorption band at 201 nm, corresponding to the charge transfer from O2- to Sn4+ in tetrahedrally coordinated (Si-O)4Sn(Ⅳ) [35,45,46]. Notably, the appearance of a band at 260 nm in the PtSn/S-1–1F and PtSn/S-1–2F catalysts suggests the transformation of tetra-coordinated Sn4+ to the hexacoordinated (Si-O)3(H2O)2Sn(Ⅵ)-OH [47,48], where Sn sites interact with the Pt species to form bimetallic Pt-Sn. Additionally, H2-TPR analysis was conducted to evaluate the reducibility of the metal species (Figure S6). No reduction peaks were observed for the PtSn/S-1 catalyst below 300 °C, likely due to the formation of metallic Pt during the synthesis process. A reduction peak at 407 °C is attributed to the partial reduction of Sn4+ to Sn2+, consistent with previous reports [49]. The weak interaction between Sn species and the support, indicated by this low reduction temperature, may cause Sn species to the segregate during PDH reaction at 550 °C, forming Pt-Sn structure riched in Sn. The PtSn/S-1 catalyst showed no reduction peak of Pt, which could be attributed to the low content of metallic platinum. This segregation leads to rapid catalyst deactivation. Consequently, the primary challenge in regeneration lies in the reconstruction of the segregated Pt@Sn bimetallic structure and restoring its catalytic activity. However, it is important to note that, based on TEM, FT-IR, 29Si MAS NMR, and UV–Vis results, the interaction between surface silanol groups on S-1 and the highly dispersed Sn species can be fully restored even after multiple regeneration cycles, maintaining its original state. Thus, the active Pt sites on PtSn/S-1 catalysts subjected to different regeneration treatments were monitored using CO-DRIFTS to unveil the changes in the electronic structure during regeneration cycles. In Fig. 5d, the vibration band at 2046 cm-1 corresponds to the on-top linear adsorbed CO on isolated Pt sites of PtSn/S-1–1F, PtSn/S-1–1U, and PtSn/S-1–15U [50]. However, for PtSn/S-1–2F, no vibration signal associated with CO adsorption on Pt sites is observed, indicating that the catalytic active PtSn bimetal structure has been restructuring during regeneration in oxygen, forming a structure with a Sn-rich surface with a Pt core. This phenomenon demonstrates that the reducible nature of Sn species causes significant segregation of Pt@Sn bimetallic structure during the reaction, leading to rapid deactivation. During regeneration, the PtSn bimetallic structure is effectively redispersed, restoring the surface Pt-rich bimetallic active sites. As indicated above, the silanol groups on the surface of S-1 bind to highly dispersed Sn species and modulate their reducibility. This interaction effectively promotes the redispersion of Sn species, thereby re-exposing the Pt-rich bimetallic active sites during the regeneration-dehydrogenation cycles. The chemical states of the catalysts were investigated by XPS (Fig. 6). The major binding energy peak of Pt 4f for all catalysts appeared at 71.2 eV, corresponding to the metallic Pt species in the zero valence state [51]. In addition, the peak at 72.4 eV is attributed to Pt2+ attached to the lattice oxygen atoms of the S-1 zeolite. It is well established that metal Pt0 serves as an active site in the PDH process, rather than oxidized Pt species. The Sn 3d binding energy peaks are consistently observed at 487.5 eV, with no significant variation, and are assigned to Sn4+ species [52]. Notably, the peak area of Sn4+ species gradually decreases as the reaction progresses, and Sn0 species emerge after 15 rounds of the reaction. Py-IR spectra were used to further investigate the type of acidic centers. As shown in Fig. 7 (a-b), the vibrational bands of all catalysts around 1540 and 1450 cm-1 correspond to Brönsted (B) and Lewis (L) acid sites [53,54]. The vibrational bands at 1444 and 1596 cm-1 are attributed to pyridine absorbed on the surface Lewis acid sites or hydrogen-bonded pyridine [55,56], while the weak peak at 1488 cm-1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of pyridine simultaneous interacting with both L and B acid sites [55]. Based on the semi-quantitative analysis of the content of L and B acid centers (Table 2 ), the acid centers of the catalysts remained relatively unchanged as the reaction progressed, indicating that most of the metal species remained stable during the regeneration cycles [12] The acidity of the catalysts was further determined using NH3-TPD. The NH3-TPD spectra showed a detachment peak of NH3 at 203 °C (Figure S7), which could be the Lewis acid site provided by the Sn4+ [12]. C3H6 and C3H8 adsorption and desorption tests were conducted on the catalysts, as shown in Figure S8. The C3H6 desorption peaks of the PtSn/S-1 catalysts appeared at lower temperatures [57], indicating a weak interaction between propylene and the surface of the PtSn/S-1 catalyst. The propane desorption temperature of the PtSn/S-1 catalysts is 105 °C, suggesting propane is adsorbed on both the Pt sites and the L acid site of the catalyst. This behavior explains the high propylene selectivity and improved propane conversion observed in the PDH reaction [35,58]. 4.3 Analysis of the resistance to carbon deposition on catalyst Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was used to quantify the amount of coke deposited on the spent catalyst [59]. Fig. 8 shows the weight loss as a function of temperature. The loss of carbon content of PtSn/S-1–1U was 2.6 %, whereas the loss of carbon content of PtSn/S-1–15U for 15 rounds of reaction was 16.4 %, indicating that the carbon content of the catalysts was increasing with the number of reactions. In addition, the absence of Raman spectral signals of carbon-containing species in Figure S9 excludes the presence of graphic carbon on the catalyst surface due to coke formation [60]. These results, supported by both TG and Raman data, strongly indicate that the deactivation of the PtSn/S-1 catalyst is primarily due to the weak interaction between metal and support. This weak interaction leads to the continuous segregation and reduction of Sn species in the reaction process, ultimately covering the active Pt sites. However, the abundant silanol groups on the surface of S-1 zeolite facilitate the redispersion of the Sn species in the regeneration, thereby promoting the redispersion of the active Pt sites and restoring the activity of the catalyst. 5 Conclusions In summary, the PtSn/S-1 catalyst exhibited an initial propane dehydrogenation (PDH) activity of 22.2 %, which increased to 44 % after one oxygen regeneration cycle, with 15 stable dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles achieved. Silanol groups in PtSn/S-1 promote the high dispersion of Sn species, which serve as nucleation sites for Pt atom redispersion during oxidative regeneration. The formation of a Pt-rich bimetallic structure is critical to suppressing Sn segregation during PDH. While coke deposition occurs, its quantity does not correlate with activity loss. This work demonstrates that silanol-Sn interactions facilitate Pt redispersion, with the enhanced performance of Sn-promoted Pt catalysts attributed to silanol-mediated metal redispersion during regeneration. These findings emphasize the need to design catalysts with stable active sites and dynamic reconfiguration capabilities, offering a novel strategy for industrial catalyst regeneration and advancing sustainable PDH processes. coredata.dc:description: PtSn bimetallic catalysts applied in propane dehydrogenation (PDH) reaction suffer from deactivation at high temperatures (500–700 °C) due to metal segregation and Sn-rich cluster formation. This study demonstrates that supporting PtSn catalysts on Silicalite-1 zeolite (S-1) enhances Sn dispersion through interactions with silanol hydroxyl groups, enabling effective regeneration of Pt-rich PtSn clusters even after 15 reaction-regeneration cycles. Comprehensive characterizations reveal that silanol nests play a critical role in redispersing metal species during regeneration, minimizing aggregation, and maintaining catalytic activity. The enhanced metal-support interactions significantly improve catalyst regenerability and stability, addressing key challenges in industrial PDH processes. This work highlights the importance of Sn dispersion and metal-support interactions in designing durable and efficient PtSn catalysts, offering practical insights for sustainable propylene production.

coredata.dc:title: Silanol nest-driven redispersion of sintered PtSn clusters in zeolite for regenerable propane dehydrogenation
